Award.AwardTitle: Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory, 2014/2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for the Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory for the 2014/2015 academic year. This series consists of three mini-conferences in Atlanta, on the campuses of Emory University, Georgia Institute of Technology, and Georgia State University. These conferences will be scheduled in November 2014, February 2015, and April 2015. Each conference will feature two one-hour lectures by one distinguished researcher, several one-hour lectures by established researchers mainly from the Southeast, and several thirty-minute talks by junior researchers and graduate students.

The Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory, begun in 2010, has become a major event for the combinatorics community in the Southeast, providing opportunities to strengthen collaborations among researchers and institutes within the southeast region of the United States. The featured lectures and other invited talks cover a variety of topics in graph theory and combinatorics. These conferences have inspired young researchers and will continue to provide opportunities for young researchers and graduate students to interact with each other and with established researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the academic year 2014-2015, three mini-conferences of the Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory were succesfully organized:

  • The 13th mini-conference at Emory University, November 1-2, 2014
  • The 14th mini-conference at Georgia State University, February 14-15, 2015
  • The 15th mini-conference at Georgia Institute of Technology, April 11-12, 2015

ALS13: Organizer Ronald J. Gould, Emory University

The 13th conference featured two 1-hour talks by Peter Keevash, Oxford University, as well as hour talks by Stephen Hartke (University of Nebraska-Lincoln); Fred Roberts (Rutgers University); Charlie Colbourn (Arizonia State University); and Yi Zhao (Georgia State University).

These talks were supplemented by 25 minute talks by Blair Sullivan (North Carolina State University); Yufei Zhao (MIT);  Theo Molla (University of Illinois);  and Carl Yerger (Davidson).  Thus, as proposed, the mini-conference featured one of the top combinatorialists in the country and four other major researchers, as well as provided an opportunity for some young faculty and graduate students to present their work. As such, we met all our goals stated in the proposal.

There were 72 registered participants.

ALS14: Organizer Guantao Chen,  Georgia State University

The 14th conference featured two 1-hour talks by Jozsef Balogh, from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Also featured were four 1 hour talks by Boris Bukh (Carnegie Mellon University); Shuhong Gao (Clemson University); Hao Huang (Institute of Mathematics and its Applications, University of Minnesota; and Iowa State University); and Chris Rodger (Auburn University).

These talks were supplemented by 25 minute talks by young faculty and graduate students including graduate student, Carl Georg Heise (Hamburg University of Technology); Bernard Lidicky (Iowa State University);  Colton Magnant (Georgia Southern University); Shoichi Tsuchiya (Keio University).

Thus, as proposed, the mini-conference featured one of the top combinatorialists in the country and four other major researchers, as well as provided an opportunity for some younger faculty and graduate students to present their work. As such, we met all our goals stated in the proposal.

These 10 researchers received travel and local expense support to speak at the conference. Also, as in our proposal, Professor Balogh received a larger honorarium for his extra efforts. Additionally,  in combining with support from the Department of Mathematics of Georgia State University,  we supported 10 more local researchers and graduate students to attend the conference.

As in our proposal, these 9 researchers received travel and local expense support to speak at the conference. The mini-conference was very well attended with 73  registered participants and 63 participants signed in.

ALS15: Organizer Xingxing Yu, Georgia Institute of Technology
